repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Grants for Emergency Household
            Survey and Policies for Poverty Reduction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Household Survey and
            Policies for Poverty Reduction Project for Iraq had a
            moderately satisfactory outcome, with the performance of the
            Bank being deemed moderately satisfactory, while the
            performance of the grantee was felt to be satisfactory. Of
            the five project development objectives indicators, three
            were achieved, one was partially achieved, and one was not
            achieved. Of the nine intermediate outcome indicators, two
            were not achieved, while the remaining indicators were
            achieved. Significant lessons learned during the course of
            project implementation were: 1) a fragile government working
            in an unstable environment cannot be expected to produce
            results quickly, particularly when public institutions are
            weak; 2) having a Bank executed trust fund paired with a
            recipient executed trust fund proved to be an extremely
            constructive approach which might be replicated elsewhere;
            3) building government capacity to collect data and do
            policy analysis does not necessarily mean there are
            meaningful results in terms of policy reform and poverty
            reduction; and 4) if risks to development outcomes are very
            high, having a long list of mitigation measures should not
            be used to create an illusion that risks no longer exist.

repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Household Survey and Policies for
            Poverty Reduction Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Household Survey
            and Policies for Poverty Reduction Project is to strengthen
            the ability of the Government of Iraq (GoI) to make and
            implement informed policies regarding poverty reduction, job
            creation and improvement of safety nets in Iraq. This is a
            level two restructuring to extend the closing date. The
            extension of the closing dates is necessary to ensure that
            the project continues to provide logistical support to the
            continued implementation and completion of the second Iraq
            Household and Socio-economic Survey (IHSES-2). The extension
            of the closing date is necessary to ensure that the World
            Bank has sufficient time to deliver technical assistance
            (TA) activities and build capacity for relevant policy
            analysis of data and production of the poverty estimates and
            their determinants, which will feed into the formulation of
            the second Poverty Reduction Strategy (PRS) in 2013. The
            need for extension arises from the delays in forming a
            government after the 2010 election, which slowed down the
            functioning of the government, as well as security concerns
            impacting on the ability to conduct field activities. This
            will be the fourth and final extension of the closing date.

display_title.display_title:
Iraq - Household Survey and
            Policies for Poverty Reduction Project : restructuring (Vol.
            2) : Data sheet
